tasks: Testing degree heterogeneity in directed networks
results: The null distribution of the normalized log-likelihood ratio statistic converges to a standard normal distribution as r → ∞
The log-likelihood ratio statistic converges to a chi-square distribution with r-1 degrees of freedom as n → ∞
Real-world data analysis demonstrates the presence of degree heterogeneity in different network datasets
title: Testing Degree Heterogeneity in Directed Networks.pdf
abstract: We are concerned with the likelihood ratio tests in the p0 model for testing degree heterogeneity in directed networks. It is an exponential family distribution on directed graphs with the out-degree sequence and the in-degree sequence as naturally sufficient statistics. For two growing dimensional null hypotheses: a specified null H0 : θi = θ0 i for i = 1, . . . , r and a homogenous null H0 : θ1 = · · · = θr, we reveal high dimensional Wilks’ phenomena that the normalized log-likelihood ratio statistic, [2{ℓ(bθ)−ℓ(bθ 0)}−r]/(2r)1/2, converges in distribution to a standard normal distribution as r →∞. Here, ℓ(θ) is the log-likelihood function, bθ is the unrestricted maximum likelihood estimator (MLE) of θ, and bθ 0 is the restricted MLE for θ under the null H0. For the homogenous null H0 : θ1 = · · · = θr with a fixed r, we establish the Wilks-type theorem that 2{ℓ(bθ)−ℓ(bθ 0)} converges in distribution to a chi-square distribution with r−1 degrees of freedom as n →∞, not depending on the nuisance parameters. These results extend a recent work by Yan et al. (2023) to directed graphs. Simulation studies and real data analyses illustrate the theoretical results. Key words: Degree heterogeneity, Directed graphs, Likelihood ratio tests, Wilks- type theorems. 1 Introduction The degree heterogeneity is a very common phenomenon in real-world networks, which describes variation in degrees of nodes.
